comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
See thats the thing about Munster people, they are so much better behaved than their northern brothers and sisters!  Look at the relaxed attitude of the passengers as they allow the ladies to go first (to check that the gangway is safe).
As to the debate as to whether SS stood for steam or sail - Wikipedia comes down strongly in favour of Steam as Sailing Vessels had the designation SV (which I never ever saw being used:-0)

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
Shannon is a very famous name when it comes to ships.  The English frigate Shannon was involved in a famous battle against  over USS Chesapeake and was one of the very few to come through with a victory over a US ship off Boston.  
As far as I remember there was a Shannon serving the Shannon estuary right up to the 60's

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: c1892-1918 PS Shannon Waterford SS Co.& Limerick SS Co. Paddle steamer. (from here.) More: 1892 15th February (CJ). Lower Shannon Steamships Sailing for February: From Limerick: Monday 15th : 9 am: Wednesday 10 am: Friday 10am: Monday 22nd 12 o’clock: Tuesday 3 pm: Friday 2 pm: Monday 29th 9 am: From Kilrush: Tuesday 16th 12 o’clock: Thursday 2 pm: Saturday 2 pm: Tuesday 23rd 9 am: Wednesday 6 pm: Saturday 11 am; 1892 16th July (KH) The new SS “Shannon” built for the Waterford Steamship Company arrived in Limerick on Wednesday from Belfast. The “Shannon” is specially adapted to its passenger’s traffic and is lighted throughout by electricity. The refreshment cabin is under the Company own management. The steamer is intended to run on the passenger service commencing on next Wednesday. 1892 28th July (CJ). Excursion: On Sunday the new steamer Shannon ------ ran a special excursion from Kilrush to the City of the Violated Treaty.---- The popular manager at Kilrush Mr. H. G. Supple also travelled---.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: I've noted a structure on the horizon to the top right of the picture which is simply called "The Square" on the 1896 map. There is a tower and boundary wall still standing maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&ll=52.630018,-9.492443&... which are listed as protected structures in the Clare County Development Plan and described as a "barracks". Can't find anymore info on it but it could give a clue to the date of the photo.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: I was always told SS was steamship, MV was motor vessel (non-steam powered)

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
MV was added later as diesel ships appeared.

RMS stands for Royal Mail Ship or Royal Mail Steamer (the use has changed somewhat over time as steam power was replaced). Ships are only supposed to use the RMS designation when they are under contract to the Royal Mail in the UK to carry mail on behalf of the British government, and have the right to fly the pennant of the Royal Mail while doing so. Because there were usually penalties for late delivery of the mail, ships with the RMS designation had a reputation for being operated on a very punctual basis, which was an advantage to the passengers.

The USS designation stands for United States Ship, and is used specifically for ships with active commissions in the US Navy.

comment.author: 94761324@N03
comment._content: My great grandfather, John Colivet, captained the S.S. Shannon ship for a number of years so it is great to see a photo of such quality from that time. He was a French immigrant to Limerick. He later went back to sea on the Aylevarroo which was torpedoed off Ballycotton during WW1.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: There are two possible John Colivets in the 1901 census. One is a 2nd Mate, one of many Residents of a house ship in Samphire (Ballynahaglish, Kerry) The other is a family man in Galway, a Master Mariner. Both are listed as originally from Jersey. I think the second one is probably your great grandfather, as he shows up in Limerick in 1911.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/94761324@N03] Lovely to hear from you, and great that you found this photo! Was your great grandfather [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley]'s John Colivet above, the Master Mariner?

And did he survive the torpedoing?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 94761324@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Hi Niall, thanks for the reply, I'm only seeing it now. He is recorded in Kerry and Galway on the same night! Can only assume he had filled out the one in Galway before going to sea and then ship was moored in Fenit that night...or his wife forged it!

comment.author: 94761324@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Hi, thanks, the photo stream is great. No, there were no survivors unfortunately. We only knew he was lost at sea but found out the story of the Aylevarroo thanks to other relatives who posted details online like this site and British merchant marine records. I think the decision to return to sea was out of necessity because the passenger ferry business on the Shannon was trailing off by that time. p.s. One of John's sons was Michael Colivet, a Volunteer, who was imprisoned on Spike island when the Aylevarroo was holed off Ballycotton island.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/94761324@N03] Really sorry that he didn't survive. We have this photo of the passenger saloon on the S.S. Shannon too....
